#T_RL=webanno.custom.Coref|type|BT_webanno.custom.Referent
#Text=Clean a Slate Hearth
#Text=If you have a slate hearth around your fireplace and it ’s been there for more than 2 months , it ’s probably a little dirty .
#Text=Slate hearths need to be cleaned regularly to prevent and remove the grime and stains that build up on them .
#Text=Luckily , it ’s pretty easy to clean your slate hearth , as long as you have some ordinary household cleaning supplies and a few specialty items from a home improvement store .
#Text=Steps
#Text=Performing Routine Cleaning
#Text=Sweep , dust , or vacuum the slate to remove any loose dirt .
#Text=Remove any dust , ash flakes , or other debris items from the surface of the slate hearth before you proceed to clean it with the dish soap mixture .
#Text=You can also use a dry mop if you have one .
#Text=Make sure you remove any dust or dirt in the grout trenches between the slabs of slate as well .
#Text=Make a cleaning solution out of water and dish soap .
#Text=Mix a few drops of mild dish soap into a bucket filled halfway with warm water .
#Text=Use a long wooden spoon to stir this mixture together until the dish soap is completely mixed with the water .
#Text=Use a mild dish soap to avoid inadvertently damaging the slate on your hearth .
#Text=You can also use an all-purpose surface cleaner if you do n’t have any mild dish soap .
#Text=Avoid using a bucket that ’s too small .
#Text=You should mix the dish soap with at least of water .
#Text=Scrub the slate with a cloth or mop soaked in the soapy water mix .
#Text=Dip your cloth or mop into the mixture , then ring it out slightly to get rid of excess moisture .
#Text=Then , scrub the slate using circular motions to clean it .
#Text=Do n’t apply too much pressure when you go to scrub the slate .
#Text=If a gentle once-over is n’t enough to clean off any dirt and grime on your hearth , use a more powerful cleaning solution instead .
#Text=Pay special attention to the corners , as this is where a lot of grime can build up unnoticed .
#Text=Rinse the slate with clean water to get the soap off of it .
#Text=Spray small amounts of water onto the slate with a spray bottle in order to rinse the hearth without making a mess .
#Text=You can also use a sponge soaked in clean water if you do n’t have a spray bottle handy .
#Text=You should also allow the hearth to air dry overnight if you intend to polish it after you clean it .
#Text=Use a clean towel to dry any excess moisture off of your hearth .
#Text=You can use any ordinary towel to dry the slate , so long as it ’s clean .
#Text=If you plan to do any further cleaning , allow the hearth to air dry overnight first .
#Text=Get as much of the water off of the slate as possible .
#Text=Any excess moisture left on the slate may cause water stains .
#Text=Wipe down the slate with teak oil to polish your hearth .
#Text=Use a soft cloth to apply a thin layer of teak oil to the surface of the slate .
#Text=Then , use a second clean cloth to remove any excess oil from the surface .
#Text=You can buy reasonably priced teak oil at most large hardware stores .
#Text=You can also use slate oil instead of teak oil , although the former is usually more expensive and a bit harder to find in stores .
#Text=Teak oil also helps hide scratches on your hearth , making it easier to seal .
#Text=Removing Stains
#Text=Make a cleaning solution out of hydrogen peroxide and water .
#Text=Mix equal portions of water and hydrogen peroxide in a small spray bottle .
#Text=If you do n’t have a spray bottle , you can also mix these ingredients in a bucket and use a sponge to apply it .
#Text=You can also use a mixture of equal parts of baking soda and hydrogen peroxide to provide stronger cleaning power .
#Text=You may also use 1 part rubbing alcohol with 8 parts water as an alternative .
#Text=Spray your mix of water and hydrogen peroxide onto the stain .
#Text=Apply a thin layer of the water and peroxide mixture directly to the surface of the stain .
#Text=Let the mixture sit for 5-10 minutes before proceeding .
#Text=Avoid spraying this mixture near any colored grout , since the bleach in the mixture can discolor your grout .
#Text=Scrub the stain with a soft scrub pad or brush .
#Text=Scrub in a circular motion without applying too much pressure in order to clean the slate without damaging it .
#Text=If you used baking soda and hydrogen peroxide instead of the water mixture , use a moist cloth to scrub the slate .
#Text=Refrain from using steel wool , as this might cause damage to the slate .
#Text=Allow the slate to air dry after you ’ve scrubbed the stain clean .
#Text=There ’s no need to wipe the solution off of the slate after you ’re done .
#Text=For best results , allow the slate to dry overnight before putting anything on it or using the fireplace .
#Text=Use a Trisodium Phosphate ( TSP ) mix on tougher stains .
#Text=Make a cleaning paste out of TSP and water , carefully following the manufacturer ’s instructions for use .
#Text=Spread the paste onto a sponge and use that sponge to scrub the slate .
#Text=Finally , soak a separate clean sponge in water and use it to remove any residue from the slate surface .
#Text=This method is particularly useful if the stains on your slate were caused by smoke or soot .
#Text=You can also use a commercial fireplace cleaner to help remove soot and smoke residue .
#Text=Tips
#Text=Clean the slate around your fireplace every 2-3 months to prevent the buildup of grime and stains , even if the hearth does n’t look dirty .
#Text=Seal the slate with stone and tile sealer to help protect it against moisture and stains .
#Text=Warnings
#Text=Avoid using acidic cleaners , like vinegar , since they can etch and damage the slate .
#Text=Do n’t let water pool up on your slate since the water will absorb into it .
#Text=Things You ’ll Need
#Text=Performing Routine Cleaning
#Text=Water
#Text=Dish soap
#Text=Cloth or mop
#Text=Bucket
#Text=Spray bottle
#Text=Towel
#Text=Teak
#Text=oil
#Text=Removing Stains
#Text=Water
#Text=Hydrogen peroxide
#Text=Spray bottle
#Text=Soft scrub pad or brush
#Text=Trisodium Phosphate
#Text=Sponge
